## General

This is a course for master level students enrolled in the "Biologia Evoluzionistica, Ecologia e Antropologia Applicata" degree at the University of Rome Tor Vergata. It is worth **6 CFU** for a total of 48 hours to be administered in person (or remotely, depending on the evolution of the pandemic) during the second semester of each academic year. Students participating to this class should have a good knowledge of zoology, ecology, population biology,  genetics, and molecular biology.

## Topics

Here is a brief overview of the topics covered in class. These are not set in stone and may vary throughout the course. Also, they are not always covered in the same order they are presented here.

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
1.  Introduction to conservation biology
2.  Biodiversity
3.  Biodiversity and extinctions
4.  Basics of conservation genetics
5.  Population size
6.  Genetic drift
7.  Inbreeding depression
8.  Population structure
9.  Hybridization
10. Population viability analysis
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
11. Invasive species
12. Managing genetic diversity in the wild
13. Managing genetic diversity in captive populations
14. Applying genetic information to conservation
15. Conservation and climate change
16. Future climate impacts
17. Conservation economics
18. Conservation technology
:::
:::
